Determining the exact force required to break a wrist while grasping it as shown in the image depends on many factors including:

- The precise location of force application on the wrist bones
- The direction and angle of the applied force
- The biomechanical properties of the bones and surrounding tissues (which vary with age, health, and individual differences)
- The duration and nature (static or dynamic) of the force

However, in general terms, the human wrist bones (radius and ulna and associated carpal bones) can withstand forces in the range of approximately 200-400 newtons (N) before fracturing under typical conditions. Gripping the wrist as shown may distribute the force differently, potentially requiring more or less force depending on leverage, grip strength, and body positioning.

Additionally, forces causing rotational torque or leverage on the wrist joint can cause fractures or dislocations at lower force thresholds than direct compressive forces.

If you are designing a robotic manipulator or safety system, it's important to have detailed biomechanical analysis and ideally consult biomechanical or medical expertise. For exact numeric thresholds, experimental data from biomechanical testing specific to the application would be necessary.

If you want, I can help estimate approximate forces or torques involved if you provide more data such as the type of force applied, lever arm lengths, or material properties of the components involved.
